content: @simulacrum @Pietro Albini do either of you know if it's possible for me to be on the FCP list for RFCs but not for std PRs? i took myself off the FCP list a long time ago because i wasn't able to reliably keep up with FCPs against std, but RFCs have a much lower volume that i think i can keep up with.
I can check, but I suspect no
We could have a separate libs-rfc team though or something like that
It's also not out of the question to have someone register a concern for you on any new RFC FCP
aye okay, thanks for checking! i'll keep the more informal process in mind.
I kind of like the idea of a libs-rfcs team to be honest
aye, i would certainly prefer that :)
@simulacrum Would there be a lot of churn in introducing an RFCs team for libs? Is that something we could reasonably do?
hm, not sure I follow -- you mean a dedicated team for fcpbot?
https://github.com/rust-lang/team/blob/master/teams/libs.toml#L27 is the specification currently
Sorry, I pulled this stream back up out of nowhere :smile: Yeh, so we can have a different set of folks tagged for RFCs than for high-five
Ah I see. So we would set up a new team and change this line: https://github.com/rust-lang/team/blob/master/teams/libs.toml#L30
Yes, I think so
It should just be a matter of adding another team/t-libs-rfc.toml file, for example
So those config files automagically sync with GitHub teams?
I know there's some sync that goes on but am not super sure how it all works :smile:
sort of
that's these lines https://github.com/rust-lang/team/blob/master/teams/libs.toml#L16-L17
that pulls the name of the team and creates a github team of that same name with the members in that team
https://github.com/rust-lang/team#rust-teams-structure has a list of what gets autosynced and how often
and the schema is documented here https://github.com/rust-lang/team/blob/master/docs/toml-schema.md
Gotcha. Thanks @simulacrum! So shall I just PR up a new team config then and we'll work out the detes there?
yep, that'd be great!
I am able to review and merge such PRs
rfcbot has a few more dependencies on the team name, so it might be easier to have a t-libs-highfive team instead.
(For instance, I think rfcbot assumes the team name matches the label on an issue, and similarly if you want to rfcbot poll you need the team name.)
Highfive doesn't sync with GitHub teams or use them at all I think
I am not sure about the second point, though.

Sorry I'm just getting around to this now :smile: So it looks like highfive has its own config that's independent of the team structure. For libs we have this list: https://github.com/rust-lang/highfive/blob/master/highfive/configs/rust-lang/rust.json#L7-L9
So I think all we need to do is unexclude @BurntSushi from the rfcbot list and we should be good?
https://github.com/rust-lang/team/pull/429

@Ashley Mannix thanks! so my thing wasn't "i want to be on FCP but not on the review rotation," but rather, "i want to be on the FCP list for RFCs but ideally nothing else, including FCPs against std." but if that's not possible, i'll try out being on the FCP list for both and see if i can keep up.
in other words, i'd like to have a voice in major changes, but don't really have the bandwidth to keep up with every individual API change made to std.
Ahh hmm ok. So that's why we were thinking about a separate team for rust, not for highfive, but for FCPs there
It looks like we've currently got 7 FCPs active: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aopen+label%3Aproposed-final-comment-period+label%3AT-libs
